para.paratext: Under Georgia evidence law prior to 2013, “[d]eclarations accompanying an act, or so nearly connected therewith in time as to be free from all suspicion of device or afterthought, [were] admissible in evidence as part of res gestae.”[1] In Andrews v. State,[2] the Georgia Supreme Court reviewed precedent discussing the res gestae hearsay exception, terming it the “near-insoluble enigma of our law,” and Justice Gregory concluded that “[r]es gestae is a Gordian Knot, which no one has succeeded in untying.”[3]

Fortunately, with the adoption of the new Evidence Code, the Georgia legislature took the opportunity to retire the very confusing concept of res gestae (meaning “thing done”) and replace it with O.C.G.A. § 24-8-803(1), (2), and (3), which provides three time-tested hearsay exceptions for (1) declarations describing or explaining a “present sense impression,”[4] (2) declarations which qualify as an “excited utterance,” and (3) declarations illustrating a “then existing mental, emotional, or physical condition.”

Application of the federal rules require a reasonable temporal proximity between the statement and the event and that the declarant have personal knowledge of the matter that the statement is offered to prove.[5] Fed. R. Evid. 803(3) is quite broad and applies to statements of “the declarant's then existing state of mind, emotion, sensation, or physical condition (such as intent, plan, motive, design, mental feeling, pain, and bodily health).”

See Owens v. State, 329 Ga. App. 455, 765 S.E.2d 653 (2014), where the court held that, once the trial court made the determination that statements made to a 911 operator were nontestimonial, they fell within the present sense impression exception to hearsay and were properly admitted by the trial court.
For further discussion of the federal rules, see Goode and Wellborn, Courtroom Handbook on Federal Evidence.
